Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Commercially Viable Ton-Scale Production of Stereoblock Polypropylene Thermoplastic Elastomers and XPURE? Oils
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to use the transformational "living coordinative chain transfer polymerization" (LCCTP) technology of Precision Polyolefins, LLC (PPL) to produce new classes of polyolefins from readily available, inexpensive, and renewable chemical feedstocks and that can be used in the manufacturing of consumer products with superior performance to the benefit of society. More specifically, the commercial production of structurally-well-defined (precise) polyolefins, including stereoblock polypropylene (sbPP) thermoplastic elastomers, as replacements for technologically inferior polyolefins in adhesive and additives markets will serve to capitalize on the increasingly advantaged position of inexpensive propylene in the North America. The development of new technologies, such as LCCTP, will help the U.S. to regain its position as a world-leader in the discovery and commercialization of new polyolefin-based materials, and thereby, contribute to the future health and growth of the U.S. economy.

The objectives of the proposed Phase II research project are to address the needs for new commercial polymers against a back-drop of ever increasing consumer demand, a sluggish industrial response, and a limited pool of chemical feedstocks possessing high price and supply volatility from which they can be manufactured. The current project will seek to develop commercially-viable processes based on a living coordinative chain transfer polymerization (LCCTP) technology to provide a broad range of structurally-well-defined polyolefins that possess with superior properties relative to existing products. By conducting an in-depth investigation of polymerization catalyst structure / property relationships, the project will seek to optimize catalyst activity and thermal stability. In concert with scale-up process development, this catalyst optimization will lead to reduced material and processing costs, and a product portfolio of competitively-priced polyolefins with superior performance characteristics. Validation of an optimized scale-up process will be achieved through the ton-scale production of stereoblock polypropylene (sbPP) thermoplastic elastomers, for adhesive and additive markets, and low molecular weight proprietary oils, for cosmetics, lubricants, and adhesives markets. The anticipated result is that commercially relevant (> 1 kiloton) volumes of sbPP thermoplastic elastomers and proprietary oils can be manufactured as technologically and commercially viable products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding was provided for the development and validation of commercially viable processes for the single-batch, one-ton scale volume production of sbPP stereoblock polypropylene thermoplastic elastomers and nPAO polyalphaolefin oils of extremely narrow molecular weight distribution.  sbPP thermoplastic elastomers are being commercialized for applications within the adhesives market and nPAO oils are being commercialized as base stock oils and property modifiers within the lubricants market.  The principal goal of this research was to facilitate the commercialization of PPL’s polyolefin products by demonstrating the commercial viability of processes for their production, documenting their performance advantages, and securing the availability of large volumes of sbPP and nPAO materials for the formulation and testing of finished lubricants and adhesives.

Having previously validated protocols for the production of stereoblock polypropylene thermoplastic elastomers on the pilot scale, during the period of this award new initiator and polymerization technologies were validated within a pilot-scale, 200-liter reactor that yielded 100-kilograms of two different well-defined polyalphaolefin oils possessing a targeted molecular weight and exceptionally narrow molecular weight distribution with high reactor volume efficiencies and chemical yields. The successful validation of these processes on the 200-liter scale will enable the 4000-liter, ton-scale, single-batch, and subsequent kilo-ton, multi-batch, commercial production of PPL’s polyolefin materials. Work performed under the SBIR Phase II award also led to the successful development of a laboratory scale continuous flow process which has the potential to significantly reduce the cost of producing polyalphaolefin oils relative to a single batch process.

Evaluation of nPAO oils as components in lubricating oil formulations demonstrated that these extremely narrow polydispersity oils met or exceeded the performance of state of the art commercial oils across several key metrics. Crucially, nPAO oils, by virtue of their narrow polydispersity, possess exceptionally high mechanical (shear) stability allowing the formulation of synthetic lubricants with increased performance at temperature extremes, which can deliver enhanced energy efficiency and durability for automotive and industrial equipment.

This project has demonstrated the commercial and technical viability of producing previously inaccessible advanced polymeric materials on a multi-ton scale using commodity feedstocks.  The anticipated result of the project is that commercially relevant (> 1 kiloton) volumes of stereoblock polypropylene thermoplastic elastomers and nPAO polyalphaolefin oils will be produced as technologically and commercially viable replacements for existing technologies, and as transformational new materials in niche markets.  The successful commercialization of nPAO based lubricants will provide significant societal benefits in terms of increased economic competiveness of the US, reversed offshoring of chemical production, and increased self-sufficiency in energy and chemical feed stocks. The use of this technology to produce novel precisely structured polyolefins with unique properties for application in diverse markets, from cosmetics to commodity plastics, will facilitate the development of new and superior products, to the benefit of society, including the development of more energy efficient lubricants which can contribute to global efforts to combat climate change.  Additionally, the successful outcome of this project has highlighted the benefits of the National Science Foundation’s financial support for both academic research and subsequent SBIR small-business commercialization.
